title: Limitations of Sums of Bounded Read Formulas

A strict-interval ABP, defined in  (See Definition Â 2.1), is a restriction of the notion of interval ABPs introduced by [ref]4. In the original definition given byÂ , every sub-program in a strict-interval ABP Pğ‘ƒP is defined on a Ï€ğœ‹\pi-interval of variables for some order Ï€ğœ‹\pi, however, without loss of generality, we assume Ï€ğœ‹\pi to be the identity permutation on nğ‘›n variables. Therefore, an interval of variables [i,j],i<jğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘—[i,j],\leavevmode\nobreak\ i<j here is the set {xi,â€¦,xj}subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—\{x_{i},\ldots,x_{j}\}. In this section we show that strict-interval ABPs are equivalent to ROABPs upto a polynomial blow-up in size. The class of strict-interval ABPs is equivalent to the class of ROABPs. The proof of TheoremÂ 5.1 involves a crucial observation that in a strict-interval ABP, variables are read in at most two orders and the nodes that correspond to paths that read in different orders can be isolated. We start with some observations on intervals in [1,n]1ğ‘›[1,n] and the intervals involved in a strict interval ABP. We begin with an observation on the structure of intervals of the sub-programs of Pğ‘ƒP.
Let vğ‘£v be a node in Pğ‘ƒP. We say vğ‘£v is an ascending node, if Is,vâª¯Iv,tprecedes-or-equalssubscriptğ¼ğ‘ ğ‘£subscriptğ¼ğ‘£ğ‘¡I_{s,v}\preceq I_{v,t} and a descending node if Iv,tâª¯Is,vprecedes-or-equalssubscriptğ¼ğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptğ¼ğ‘ ğ‘£I_{v,t}\preceq I_{s,v}. Consider any sğ‘ s to tğ‘¡t path ÏğœŒ\rho in Pğ‘ƒP. We say that ÏğœŒ\rho is ascending if every node in ÏğœŒ\rho except sğ‘ s and tğ‘¡t is ascending. Similarly, ÏğœŒ\rho is called descending if every node in ÏğœŒ\rho except sğ‘ s and tğ‘¡t is descending. Let Pğ‘ƒP be a strict interval ABP and let ÏğœŒ\rho any sğ‘ s to tğ‘¡t path in Pğ‘ƒP. Therefore, Jâª¯Jâ€²precedes-or-equalsğ½superscriptğ½â€²J\preceq J^{\prime} by the transitivity of âª¯precedes-or-equals\preceq, a contradiction. This completes the proof. LemmaÂ 5.4 implies that the set of all non-terminal nodes of Pğ‘ƒP can be partitioned into two sets such that there is no edge from one set to the other. Formally: Let Pğ‘ƒP be an interval ABP. There exist two strict-interval ABPs P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} and P2subscriptğ‘ƒ2P_{2} such that All non-terminal nodes of P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} are ascending nodes and all non-terminal nodes of P2subscriptğ‘ƒ2P_{2} are descending nodes; and P=P1+P2ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ƒ1subscriptğ‘ƒ2P=P_{1}+P_{2}. Let P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} be the sub-program of Pğ‘ƒP obtained by removing all descending nodes from Pğ‘ƒP and P2subscriptğ‘ƒ2P_{2} be the sub-program of Pğ‘ƒP obtained by removing all ascending nodes in Pğ‘ƒP. By LemmaÂ 5.4, the non-terminal nodes in P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} and P2subscriptğ‘ƒ2P_{2} are disjoint and every sğ‘ s to tğ‘¡t path ÏğœŒ\rho in Pğ‘ƒP is either a sğ‘ s to tğ‘¡t path in P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} or a sğ‘ s to tğ‘¡t path in P2subscriptğ‘ƒ2P_{2} but not both. Thus P=P1+P2ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ƒ1subscriptğ‘ƒ2P=P_{1}+P_{2}. Next we show that any strict-interval ABP consisting only of ascending or only of descending nodes can in fact be converted into an ROABP. Let Pğ‘ƒP be a strict-interval ABP consisting only of ascending nodes or only of descending nodes. This establishes that Pğ‘ƒP is an one ordered ABP. By the equivalence between one ordered ABPs and ROABPs (, ), we conclude that the polynomial computed by Pğ‘ƒP can also be computed by a ROABP of size polynomial in the size of Pğ‘ƒP. Since branching programs are layered, any multilinear polynomial computed by a ROABP where variables occur in the order given by Ï€ğœ‹\pi can also be computed by a ROABP where variables occur in the reverse of Ï€ğœ‹\pi. Let Pğ‘ƒP be a ROABP where variables occur in the order induced by a permutation Ï€ğœ‹\pi. The polynomial computed by Pğ‘ƒP can also be computed by a ROABP of same size as Pğ‘ƒP that reads variables in the reverse order corresponding to Ï€ğœ‹\pi. Let Pâ€²superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²P^{\prime} be the ROABP obtained by reversing the edges of Pğ‘ƒP and swapping the start and terminal nodes. Since Pğ‘ƒP is a layered DAG, there is a bijection between the set of all sğ‘ s to tğ‘¡t paths in Pğ‘ƒP and the set of all sğ‘ s to tğ‘¡t paths in Pâ€²superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²P^{\prime}, where the order of occurrence of nodes and hence the edge labels are reversed. This completes the proof. The above observations immediately establish TheoremÂ 5.1. Let Pğ‘ƒP be a strict-interval ABP of size Sğ‘†S computing a multilinear polynomial fğ‘“f. By LemmaÂ 5.6 there are strict interval ABPs P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} and P2subscriptğ‘ƒ2P_{2} such that P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} has only ascending non-terminal nodes and P2subscriptğ‘ƒ2P_{2} has only descending non-terminal nodes such that f=f1+f2ğ‘“subscriptğ‘“1subscriptğ‘“2f=f_{1}+f_{2} where fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} is the polynomial computed by Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i}, iâˆˆ{1,2}ğ‘–12i\in\{1,2\}. By LemmaÂ 5.8 and ObservationÂ 4, f1subscriptğ‘“1f_{1} and f2subscriptğ‘“2f_{2} can be computed by a ROABPs that read the variables in the order x1,â€¦,xnsubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}. Then f1+f2subscriptğ‘“1subscriptğ‘“2f_{1}+f_{2} can also be computed by an ROABP.
It remains to bound the size of the resulting ROABP. Note that ğ—Œğ—‚ğ—“ğ–¾â€‹(Pi)â‰¤Sğ—Œğ—‚ğ—“ğ–¾subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–ğ‘†{\sf size}(P_{i})\leq S. A ROABP for fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} can be obtained by staggering the reads of Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i} which blows up the size of the ABP by a factor of nğ‘›n (, ). Therefore size of the resulting ROABP is at most 2â€‹nâ€‹Sâ‰¤Oâ€‹(S2)2ğ‘›ğ‘†ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘†22nS\leq O(S^{2}). Using TheoremÂ 5.1, we can design the following white-box PIT for strict-interval ABPs. Given a strict-interval ABP Pğ‘ƒP of size sğ‘ s, we can check whether the polynomial computed by Pğ‘ƒP is identically zero in time Oâ€‹(polyâ€‹(S))ğ‘‚polyğ‘†O(\text{poly}(S)). The proof follows from TheoremÂ 5.1 and the polynomial time white-box PIT algorithm given by  for non-commutative ABPs, since the variables in Xğ‘‹X are read only once, in a fixed order, in a ROABP. The notion of intervals of variables corresponding to every sub-program can be applied to formulas in the form of Interval Formulas, where every sub-formula corresponds to an interval. In the following section we explore how such a model can be used to generalize the model of ROFs, and in what ways it differs from ROFs.
